description: From Latin stipulātus, perfect active participle of stipulor (“I demand a guarantee”).

verbs.description: stipulate (third-person singular simple present stipulates, present participle stipulating, simple past and past participle stipulated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To require (something) as a condition of a contract or agreement.
examples: My contract stipulated that I would make dinner for him at six o'clock and leave at seven after finishing the dishes; but the Professor began objecting to this schedule as soon as my son arrived on the scene.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To specify, promise or guarantee something in an agreement.
(US, transitive, formal, law) To acknowledge the truth of; not to challenge.
examples: The defense stipulates that the witness has identified my client.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by for) To ask for a contractual term.
(botany) Having stipules; that is, having outgrowths borne on either side of the base of the leafstalk.
